awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Systems Approach to Determine Adaptive Mechanisms of Thermal Tolerance in a Model Ectotherm
awd_abstract_narration:
Populations of coastal, estuarine species like the starlet sea anemone, Nematostella vectensis, experience large fluctuations in temperature and salinity, requiring that individuals are capable of tolerating a wide range of environmental conditions. This species is widely distributed along the Atlantic coast of North America from Nova Scotia to South Carolina, with different populations along this latitudinal gradient displaying marked differences in a number of traits. The shallow, coastal environments inhabited by this species have high societal and ecological importance, yet few studies have examined how key species are adapted to these thermally dynamic environments. This work will identify the genetic basis of the integrated physiological and behavioral responses of individuals of starlet sea anemone collected from different coastal populations and raised under thermal stress. The research will lead directly to predictions about the evolutionary forces acting in these dynamic habitats. The project includes outreach efforts at community colleges and K-12 institutions, along with research experiences for minority undergraduate students. 

The investigators will determine metabolic, transcriptional, and bioenergetic responses to acute and chronic temperature stress in four populations of N. vectensis. They will also identify variation in individual movement and burrowing times through rapid phenotyping using time-lapse behavioral analyses. The behavioral and physiological data will be integrated with the metabolite and gene expression assays to determine the molecular mechanisms of the bioenergetic changes and how these correlate with temperature from each geographic location. The environmental relevance of this species' broad geographic distribution in thermally dynamic environments with the unique suite of molecular, genomic and physiological toolkits allows novel tests of hypotheses about adaptation and physiological acclimation to temperature in natural populations.

por.por_cntn:
Temperature is a key environmental factor that affects physiology, survival and distribution of all organisms by affecting the rates of biochemical and physiological reactions. Seasonal variation in temperature coupled with climate change presents a particular challenge for organisms living in isolated habitats, like salt marshes, where organisms confront barriers to migration, and therefore rely on a combination of behavior to minimize exposure to stressors, existing physiological plasticity to acclimate to these changes, and genetic adaptation to the shifting environment. In this project, we used a multidisciplinary approach combining field work and laboratory experiments to determine the contributions of behaviors, physiological acclimation, and genetic variation for temperature responses in populations of the cnidarian Nematostella vectensis distributed along the Atlantic coast of North America. 

We completed field collections to establish laboratory populations of anemones from locations along the Atlantic coast of North America. During these collections, we deployed temperature loggers to collect data over the course of the year that yielded an in depth characterization of temperature dynamics in these habitats. These temperature profiles significantly augment our understanding how these environments by detailing the short and longer term shifts in these isolated habitat that existing buoys cannot capture. It opens the way for combining temperature data from different coastal habitats to develop improved models for how organisms occupying different regions of the coast may respond to temperature variation.

In laboratory experiments, we showed that anemones from each location have significant differences in physiological and molecular responses to temperature. We utilized the field temperatures to design laboratory exposures that match the thermal environment from their native locations. We employed new techniques and analysis approaches to quantify the changes in gene expression and metabolite abundance in individuals from each location. Results from these approaches revealed unexpected differences in how individuals from each location responded to changes in thermal environment, particularly for lower latitude populations.  Importantly, these results identified particular genes and metabolites that were diagnostic for thermal responses for geographic regions, and thus are potential biological markers for future research aimed at monitoring natural populations. The physiological and molecular data have generated specific new hypotheses to causally connect how geographically partitioned genetic variation may be functionally tied to individual variation in behavioral, physiological, or molecular traits. The avenues of research covered by this project have been productive in closing this important gap of knowledge for coastal species.

This project resulted in Broader Impacts related to research training, outreach to the community, and implementing new courses. Student-centered training was completed for multiple graduate and undergraduate students throughout the life of the award. Students led research in the field and the laboratory, presented a conferences, and led information activities for current and incoming undergraduate students majoring in STEM.  Our research successes expanded opportunities for collaborative projects with local educators, including a local science museum. Our project also resulted in the successful opportunity to design and conduct experiments using advanced molecular methods for a K-12 teacher. These experiences resulted in a publication for the teacher as well as the development of a suite of education and outreach products to broaden knowledge and participation in science in our local community.  These activities will continue after this project through both classroom instructional lessons as well as public informational displays.
